sub_topic: Prove that the Cartesian product of two sets is not associative with respect to intersection.
message_1: Determine whether the following statement is true or false: (A x B) ∩ C = A x (B ∩ C) for any non-empty sets A, B, and C.
message_2:
The given statement is false.

To see why, let's first understand what each side of the equation represents.

(A x B) represents the Cartesian product of sets A and B, which consists of all ordered pairs (a, b) where a is an element of A and b is an element of B.

(A x B) ∩ C represents the intersection of the Cartesian product (A x B) with set C. This would include all elements that are both in (A x B) and in C. However, since the elements of (A x B) are ordered pairs and the elements of C are not, their intersection will be an empty set, unless C itself contains ordered pairs that match those in (A x B).

On the other hand, B ∩ C represents the intersection of sets B and C, which includes all elements that are both in B and in C.

A x (B ∩ C) represents the Cartesian product of set A with the intersection of sets B and C. This consists of all ordered pairs (a, b) where a is an element of A and b is an element of (B ∩ C).

Now, let's consider an example to show that the given statement is false.

Let A = {1}, B = {2}, and C = {2}. Then,

(A x B) = {(1, 2)}
(B ∩ C) = {2}
A x (B ∩ C) = {(1, 2)}

However, (A x B) ∩ C = ∅ (empty set) since there are no elements in C that are ordered pairs.

So, (A x B) ∩ C ≠ A x (B ∩ C), and the given statement is false.
